results.content: A useful kick-start for using firebase services, although lessons 18 and 19 were a little longer than they needed to be (might be worth re-recording without the drawn out debugging).  On the whole, I found the course helpful by following the entire lessons.  There are several areas that I would code differently (e.g. one method only for provider sign-in by feeding in a provider name, also not having all code in a single file) but on the whole a good course.  Thanks.
results.content_html: A useful kick-start for using firebase services, although lessons 18 and 19 were a little longer than they needed to be (might be worth re-recording without the drawn out debugging). On the whole, I found the course helpful by following the entire lessons. There are several areas that I would code differently (e.g. one method only for provider sign-in by feeding in a provider name, also not having all code in a single file) but on the whole a good course. Thanks.

results.content:
The title is misleading. The security is poor, there is not env setup (locally nor added by firebase cli) and the config is fully exposed. 
I'd call it auth for beginners/intermediate, but not at all "security complete".

Its not all bad though, I liked that he made debugs on the way, I liked the profile section with the loading bar. With every course there is always something new to learn. Keep up the code work, you're on the right path sir.

I hope this doesn't offend the author, my feedback is added for him to help him improve.

Thanks!

response.content:
Bogan, as you can see from this page https://firebase.google.com/docs/web/setup the keys are not secret and are exposed. The system is designed that way. You gave the course a pretty bad score based on something that is 100% not a problem with the course but actually built into the architecture of Firebase. Also, when have you ever added a .env file for something that runs in the browser? I have considered adding this information to the course but chose not to because this is not actually that hard for people who have beginner experience with Firebase. It's also the reason why the course is intended for intermediate users. If you would have taken the part of the course that covers authorization you would have had a better understanding of how security works. Unfortunately, you took half the course and with very limited Firebase experience decided to grade it poorly. I hope in the future you take the full course before jumping to conclusions. On that note, you could have easily figured this out with one google search query. There are many articles explaining why the firebase config details are not secretive.

On this page (https://firebase.google.com/docs/web/setup) about halfway down, you can see this: 
Note: The Firebase config object contains unique, but non-secret identifiers for your Firebase project.

response.content: You insisted I add OTP (one-time password). I looked into it and it is not part of Firebase. I asked you if you were referring to passwordless or anonymous authentication as it seemed like that might be what you were talking about. Then you didn't even write me back. From my point of view that is very rude. Insisting I add something that doesn't exist then not replying? If the Firebase documentation is so easy for you to understand why did you take this course?

results.content:
The title of the course is misleading. It says Firebase Authentication and Security "Complete" Guide. But 70% of the course is not about the mentioned subject and just talks about basic HTML and CSS and not about Firebase Authentication. He made a full course about a certain topic which is Firebase Authentication but he didn't cover a lot of ground about it. A lot of Firebase Auth features are not tackled. He also mentioned "Security" on the course title but the final project is not even production-ready, the user's Google API and Secret Key is exposed on the client-side JavaScript.

On Section 1.1, the instructor said he is assuming the student knows basic HTML and CSS and yet he still spends most of the time typing HTML and styling his forms using CSS. Only a short section of each video focused on the actual subject.

On Section 1.18, encountering a bug is normal, but he can choose to pause the recording, then come back when the issue is fixed and then resume recording. That is what other Udemy instructors do. But instead, he wasted a lot of time solving a problem when the cause is just in front of him all the time but he is not reading the Dev Console logs carefully.

I didn't even bother continuing the course as Section 2 is not about Firebase Authentication anymore. It is some To Do list app which you can create even without Firebase Auth. If it is something about Auth Templates or the Phone Verification instances, it would have been better and related to the topic.

response.content:
The keys are not supposed to be hidden or secret. There is no secret key for firebase config. Not sure where you saw that? As you can see here https://firebase.google.com/docs/web/setup about halfway down the page says this "The Firebase config object contains unique, but non-secret identifiers for your Firebase project. Visit Understand Firebase Projects to learn more about this config object." 

This course is not for beginners in Firebase which you clearly are. That's why it is labeled intermediate. It's sad that your lack of basic Firebase knowledge caused you to have a bad experience. Have you ever authenticated a user with anything other than Firebase? If so you would easily see that this is the best.

Security rules are covered and that is the way you SECURE Firebase applications. 

Section two is about authorization. If you know anything about authentication you would know that this is just as important and goes hand in hand. It's obvious that this course was way above your skill level and understanding of basic authentication concepts.

results.content: I am not sure why this course would get a 4 stars but everything is really basic to the point where it is available in the Firebase documentation. I give 3-star for effort but removed 1 star for section 18 & 19. Poor presentation.

response.content:
The value you get from taking a course, like this one, is not having read the documentation in order to piece it all together. 

Combining multiple Firebase services to make an app this well coded is actually a lot harder than you might think. This is why the course receives high scores. 

If you knew all this was in the documentation why did you buy the course? Everything that is covered is provided in the description.
